_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The City of Athens, Texas developed a Risk Management Plan (RMP) to be implemented at the West Waste Water Treatment Plant (WWTP) in an effort to protect human health, to protect the environment and comply with applicable federal regulations.  This plant is operated by the City of Athens.  The plant physical address is 7100 County Road 1500, Athens, Henderson County, Texas.

This RMP has been developed to meet the standards published in the 40 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) Part 68.  These regulations were promulgated by the EPA to cover the accidental release prevention provision under the Clean Air Act 112(r)(7).  These regulations require facilities that exceed the cited threshold quantities for certain chemicals to develop a RMP.  The goal of a RMP is to focus on reducing the risk of accidental releases of certain chemicals; thereby, preventing harm to employees as well as potentially catastrophic impacts on the public.  

Entrance to the West WWTP is controlled by fencing and locked gates.  The plant is located in a semi remote area away from the general populace.  However, public traveled highways are located in the close proximity of the West WWTP.  The city utilizes chlorine gas and sulfur dioxide gas in its treatment process.   The one ton containers of chlorine gas and sulfur dioxide gas are stored within are ASME coded vessels.  During the design and construction of this plant, the engineers used guidelines set forth by the National Chlorine Institute.  All external piping is protected from accidental damage by channel iron.  The feed equipment is inspected daily.  All personnel that work inside the plant have received instructions and training in the safe handling of chlorine and ammonia gases as well as the use of self contained breathing apparatus.  Each employee is required to attend a class on how to read and interpret a Material Safety Data Sheets (MSDS) within their first six months of service.  As a first responder each has been trained in

the proper procedure to shut down the chemical feed systems, or report to the emergency response personnel.  The Athens Fire Department is responsible for writing all emergency response procedures, and coordinate all emergency responses.  A copy of the City of Athens emergency response program has been filed with the Henderson County emergency response coordinators office and is attached to the Risk Management Program document.   

All employees of the plant are required to know the locations of the emergency telephone numbers and names of individuals to contact in case of a release.  If an emergency occurs, each employee will have an assigned task.  This risk management program enhances the safety plan already in operation because it provides a clear checklist that identifies predetermined individuals and agencies that require notification and coordination.  This RMP details which individuals will respond to the release to stop it and outline the agencies responsible for evacuating appropriate areas, and for sounding the "all clear" once the leak is contained.  The plan also includes procedures for periodic review of readiness.

The primary purpose of this Risk Management Plan is to maintain the plant's level of safety and retain a record verifying the proper training for West Waste Water Treatment Plant employees.
    
Program Level Determination

There are currently three program levels.  A facility will be included in Program Level 1 if it exceeds one of the threshold quantities, but does not have any off-site consequence as determined by a hazard assessment.  Program Level 2 covers those facilities that exceed a threshold quantity, has off-site consequences, but are not regulated by the Occupational Health & Safety Administrative (OSHA).  Facilities that fall into Program Level 3 are subject to OSHA regulations, exceed a threshold quantity and have potential off-site consequence or the industry has one of the specified Standard Industrial classification

(SIC) codes.  Currently, municipalities are not subject to federal OSHA regulations, and Alabama does not have a state OSHA equivalent.  The off-site consequence analysis (Reference Section 3) indicates that there could be off-site consequences if a chemical release of chlorine gas or  sulfur dioxide gas occurred at the West Waste Water Treatment Plant; therefore, the facility falls in Program Level 2.

General Requirements

The regulations outline five specific requirements for Program Level 2 facilities.  By June 21, 1999, each facility covered under the Risk Management Program rule must have completed and submitted to the EPA a Risk Management Plan.  The EPA has requested that all submittals be transmitted electronically on their forms with appropriate figures or maps.  For reference, a copy of the form has been included within Section B- Hazard Assessment.  A facility in Program Level 2 must conduct a hazard analysis, develop a prevention plan, implement an emergency response plan, and report any chemical accidents that have occurred the past five years.

The West WWTP Risk Management Program Level 2 includes the following requirements:
 
	40 CFR A§ 68.48   Safety Information 
	40 CFR A§ 68.50   Hazard Review
	40 CFR A§ 68.52   Operating Procedures
	40 CFR A§ 68.54   Training 
	40 CFR A§ 68.56   Maintenance
	40 CFR A§ 68.58   Compliance Audits
	40 CFR A§ 68.60   Incident Investigation


Toxicology/Physical Properties

It is imperative that employees are informed about the physical properties and potential health hazards of the chemicals located at the facility.  Mishandling of the chemicals can lead to severe injury or even death; therefore, it is vital that information regarding the safe handling and use of the substances is available to all employees.  In addition, chemical interaction information should be made available to all employees as well.

Chlorine

Chlorine is listed and regulated as an extremely hazardous chemical under Secti

on 304 and can cause severe injury or death.  Chlorine is delivered to the West WWTP as liquefied compressed gas.  Chlorine gas is not explosive or flammable; however, it may support combustion.  It is a strong oxidizer and may react violently with substances such as water, ammonia, fuel oil, etc.  Chlorine gas is more dense than air (vapor density= 2.49) and tends to settle in low areas.  It has a greenish-yellow color, and a strong pungent irritating odor with an odor threshold of approximately 3.5 ppm.  At standard temperature and pressure 1 ppm chlorine is equal to 2.76 milligrams per cubic meter in air.

The primary health hazard from chlorine exposure is damage to the respiratory system. It can also irritate the mucous membranes and targets the eyes, and skin.  In extreme cases, death by suffocation can result.  Frostbite may also occur if direct contact is made with liquefied chlorine.  The National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health (NIOSH) lists 10-ppm chlorine in air as immediately dangerous to life or health (IDLH).  NIOSH recommends a ceiling value of 0.5 ppm chlorine in air while OSHA regulations list 1.0-ppm chlorine in air as the ceiling value.


Sulfur Dioxide

Sulfur dioxide is a corrosive and poisonous colorless gas with a characteristically irritating and pungent odor.  It is also regulated as an extremely hazardous substance under Section 304.  It is a nonflammable gas that reacts with water to form sulfurous acid and produce toxic and corrosive fumes.  Sulfur dioxide tends to settle in low places (vapor density = 2.62).  Sulfur dioxide is typically delivered to the site as a liquefied compressed non-flammable gas.  It is either incompatible or reacts with copper, brass, aluminum and ammonia.

Sulfur dioxide can damage the upper respiratory tract and the bronchi, as it can produce respiratory paralysis.  In addition, it can irritate the eyes as well as inflame the conjunctiva.  Exposures to this chemical can be fatal.  Sulfur d

ioxide has a suffocating odor and can be detected at low concentrations possibly by taste rather than a sense of smell.  Sulfur dioxide can be detected by taste at a concentration of approximately 0.3-ppm, and is usually detected by odor at 3-ppm. Concentration between 6-ppm and 12-ppm can irritate the nose and throat.  100-ppm of sulfur dioxide in ambient air is considered to be an IDLH condition.  OSHA regulates a maximum of 5-ppm work place air concentration of sulphur dioxide.  NIOSH recommends a 2-ppm concentration with a ceiling concentration of 5-ppm sulfur dioxide in air.  The conversion between ppm and mg/m3 is 1-ppm = 2.62 mg/m3.

If a person is exposed to this chemical, and experiences toxic symptoms such as the occurrence of irritation to the eyes, nose, and throat, they should immediately be removed to fresh air.  If the eyes are involved, they should be irrigated with large quantities of warm water.

 Worst Case  Scenario

The EPA requires that for each chemical stored that exceeds the threshold quantity, a "worst case" scenario should be performed to determine the off-site consequence of accidental release.  The EPA defines the "worst case" scenario as follows:  The largest single vessel, container or pipe that contains the chemical of concern releases the entire contents as a gas when full during a ten 
minute time period.
    
The definition also assumes that during the release, atmospheric conditions are Class F, ambient air temperature is 77 degrees Fahrenheit (F), and wind speed is 1.5 meters per second. 

Chlorine is delivered to the West WWTP in one-ton containers.  Sulfur dioxide is delivered and stored in one ton containers.

The assumed rates of release for both chlorine and sulfur dioxide are 200 pounds per minute (lbs./min).  The off-site consequence analysis was conducted in accordance with Chapter 4: Off-Site Consequence Analysis of the General Guidance For Risk Management Programs October 27, 1998.

The end point concentr

ations used in the model were based on the requirements of  40 CFR Part 68.22.  The end point concentrations are based on the Emergency Response Planning Guideline (ERPG-2) concentrations.  The ERPG-2 concentration is defined as "the airborne concentration below which it is believed that nearly all individuals could be exposed for up to one (1) hour without experiencing or developing irreversible or other serious health effects or symptoms that could impair an individual's ability to take protective action".  The end point concentrations are as follows:

0.0087 milligrams per liter(mg/l) for chlorine gas
0.0078 milligrams per liter(mg/l) for sulfur dioxide gas

In the analysis of a chlorine and sulfur dioxide, release at the West Wastewater Treatment Plant the site was classified as urban.  The results of the affected area analysis were as follows:

1.3-mile radius for chlorine
1.3-mile radius for sulfur dioxide, 


An estimated population of 563 people live within the estimated 1.3-mile radius as defined by the "Worst Case" scenario for chlorine and sulfur dioxide gas release.

Alternative Release Scenario

The regulations governing Risk Management Program require that an alternative release scenario analysis be performed in addition to the EPA defined "worst case" scenario analysis.  These release scenarios consider items such as line breaks, valve failure, seal failure, vent failure, etc.  In order to provide for the highest degree of public protection, the scenario that had the highest release rate of the chemical of concern was used in the alternate release scenario.  For chlorine, the 1 inch feed line was assumed to completely break or shear near the storage tank.  For sulfur dioxide in a similar manner, the 1 inch feed line was assumed to break or shear completely near the tank. Automatic tank shut-off valves are installed, but were considered to fail in this analysis.

The same end point concentrations were used in the "worst case" scenario.

The atmospheric stability used in the alternative analysis is a Class D; wind speed of 3 m/s and ambient temperature is 77 degrees F.  The analysis estimated a 0.2-mile radius of propagation for chlorine gas and a 0.2-mile radius for sulfur dioxide gas.  This analysis also classified the site and area as urban, and the end point distances were based on the results from the EPA's RMP*COMP(TM) Model.  This is the same model and guidance reference used in the "worst case" scenario.  The results are summarized below on the following page.

 SAFETY INFORAMTION

Chlorine
Preparedness for an emergency when dealing with a chlorine leak or spill is essential since chlorine accumulation magnifies rapidly in the atmosphere and once a leak is identified, immediate action must be taken.  Whenever possible, no person should work alone on a chlorine leak.  An emergency plan of action should be implemented and include training of personnel who could become involved in a chlorine related emergency.

Effective emergency response in handling chlorine leaks and spills depends on the effectiveness and competence of the employees on site who can assess a situation and act accordingly.  It is the responsibility of the supervisors to train their employees to use personal protective and other safety equipment properly.  It is also the responsibility of the supervisors to educate their employees properly handling of chlorine and the dangers related to the mishandling of the chemical.  In addition, employees should participate in periodic drills to review the appropriate responses and know first aid procedures as

well as who to call in case of an emergency.  These drills should include designating a person to check the chlorine monitors and wind direction indicators to determine if an evacuation is necessary, an evacuation plan, using the proper safety equipment and the proper respiratory protection to wear as well as the procedure for obtaining further assistance.  The telephone numbers of the chlorine suppliers should be posted near each telephone.  

In addition, the number for the Chlorine Institute's Emergency Plan (CHLOREP) through CHEMTREC in the United States is (800) 424-9300.  CHEMTREC is typically used to provide assistance  in emergencies involving the transportation of chlorine; however, they can provide information and assistance to on-site emergencies, as well.  They will have a listing of the locations of all chlorine emergency response kits available at the plant if proper registration was done when the kits were delivered.

If a leak occurs, local authorities shall be notified to assist with evacuation.  In some instances, depending on whether there has been a "reportable quantity" leaked, some governmental agencies must be contacted for chlorine emissions.  If an evacuation is necessary, then potentially exposed persons should move to a point upwind of the leak since chlorine is heavier than air.  If evacuation seems impractical, all air conditioners and air intake systems should be turned off; and individuals should retreat to the highest point of the building on the side away from the release.  When a person is outdoors, and they do not have respiratory protection, they should cover their mouth and nose with a wet handkerchief or cloth to reduce the effects of the exposure.
Personal protection equipment should be available outside of chlorine rooms, near each use point, away from areas that are likely subject to contamination.  Respiratory equipment should be selected based on evaluation of hazards and the degree of potential exposure.  Canister ga

s masks (for protection up to 25 ppm, maximum) or chemical cartridge respirators (up to 10 ppm) would offer adequate protection where the oxygen content in the air is greater than 19.5%.  If there is no monitoring equipment available to sample the air in the area of the leak, then use of a self-contained breathing apparatus (SCBA) with a full-face piece is recommended.

Sulfur Dioxide
Exposure to very high levels of sulfur dioxide can be life threatening. Exposure to 100 parts of sulfur dioxide per million parts of air (100 ppm) is considered immediately dangerous to life and health. Burning of the nose, throat, breathing difficulties, and severe airway obstructions are affects from inhaling sulfur dioxide. Long-term exposure to persistent levels of sulfur dioxide can affect a personA¿s health. Asthmatics have also been shown to be sensitive to the respiratory effects of low concentrations of sulfur dioxide.
TRAINING

The City of Athens maintains an emergency chlorine spill response kit on-site.  At a minimum, the on-site supervisor and designated assistant shall be properly trained in the use of chlorine, its dangers, and the proper use of the spill response kits.  All on-site personnel involved in the waste water treatment process shall be trained in the use and dangers of chlorine and sulfur dioxide.  In general, the training requirements are as follows:

1. Instruction detailing physical, chemical and toxicological properties of the chemical.
2. Instruction and drills using emergency equipment.
3. Instruction and drills using the emergency repair and spill response kits.
4. Instruction and drills implementing the emergency response plan, and administering first aid.
5. Instruction detailing reporting of releases.

Certifications
Each employee at the North waste water treatment facility will be required to understand the details of this Risk Management Program.  At the completion of the class, each employee will be assigned a responsibility to perf

orm as part of the emergency response team. This training should be updated annually, and the certificates should be maintained for audit purposes.

COMPLIANCE AUDIT

Review Schedule
This plan should be reviewed at a minimum of once each year.  If the stored quantity of chlorine changes, the plan should be modified at that time. If a release occurs at the facility, an investigation should be conducted immediately in order to determine the reason for the release so that steps can be taken to prevent future incidents.  The RMP submitted to the EPA should be updated immediately following any inventory change.  If any other chemical is added to the system, a review should be conducted to determine if it is subject to the RMP regulations.




Training Personnel
As part of the preventive maintenance and safety program, an annual refresher-training course should be conducted by supervisory personnel.  The training should include a refresher of the RMP, which includes the safety program, prevention program, and emergency response program.  As part of the safety program, a review of chemical hazards, use and maintenance of the safety equipment and use of the emergency repair and spill response kits should be completed.  In addition, those individuals assigned to a respirator should be fit tested.  The person conducting the training should be familiar with the use and hazards of chlorine, be up to date on current OSHA regulations, and knowledgeable in the use of personal protective equipment

Reporting

Chlorine and sulfur dioxide are subject to release reporting under the Emergency Planning and Community Right to Know Act (EPCRA), and the Comprehensive Emergency Response, Compensation, and Liability Act (CERCLA). The reporting threshold for chlorine is 10 pounds, and sulfur dioxide is 500 pounds.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE
   
A coordinated effort is required to respond effectively, in the event there is a release of chlorine from the Athens West Waste Water Trea

tment Plant.  This plan identifies the parties as well as outlines the methods for responding.  The response must be a joint effort between the Athens North Waste Water Treatment Plant operators, City Police, County Sheriff's Department, Athens Fire Department, and Athens Fire Department Hazard Material (Hazmat) team.

Once an alarm has been sounded, it is the plant operatorA¿s responsibility to first confirm the release, notify the fire department and the emergency response team if necessary.  Decision-making will be made by the Athens North Waste Water Treatment Plant Superintendent.  Decisions shall be made based upon the type and quantity of chlorine released.

Response Procedure

It is critical to have a response procedure documented and rehearsed in case of an emergency to ensure proper procedures are carefully followed.  During normal business hours, an on-site individual will be assigned as the supervisor that is responsible for implementing the plan.  The supervisor shall have thoroughly review this emergency plan, and have detailed knowledge of the chemical hazards and their physical properties used at this facility.  He/she must also be competent of and have the authority to make the decision to either respond to the leak or evacuate the facility.  The on-site supervisor shall be responsible for contacting and notifying the required agencies and adjacent facilities.   Maps of the excavation route and potential impact area will be displayed on site in a location accessible and visible to all employees and the public.

Once a release of gas is suspected, the Athens West Waste Water Treatment Plant site supervisor shall be notified immediately.  After the supervisor has been notified, he/she shall make an individual at the plant be responsible for notifying all of the on-site personnel of the suspected release.  The plant supervisor or other employees shall notify 911 and the City of Athens Fire Department Chief who shall then notify the City of Athe

ns Fire Department Hazmat Team. The emergency management plan for the City of Athens shall then be implemented. 

Agency Coordination

If a release occurs at the waste water treatment facility, it is critical all concerned agencies are made fully aware of associated risks of chlorine stored at the facility.  The following is a list of the agencies, telephone numbers and contact names:

Emergency Contact Numbers

Athens Fire Department Chief            (903-677-6644 or          John McQuery
					 (903-681-7862
Assistant Superintendent    		(903) 681-7455           Billy Palmer
Plant Foreman    			(903) 677-6664           Olan Timmons
Director of Utilities     		(903) 677-1735	          Gordon Mayer

 The coordinating agencies shall meet a desired site located outside the evacuated area. The purpose of the meeting will be to review this plan, review the list of chemicals stored on-site and their locations, discuss each agency's responsibility, and traffic flow.  At a minimum, an annual meeting should also be conducted so that any plan changes can be discussed.  At the meeting, each agency can review the chemical dangers and the emergency response plan.  Each agency will also be encouraged to tour the plant as frequently as they feel is necessary to keep up to date and familiar with the emergency response plan.
 
Community Awareness

A vital part of implementing an effective emergency response plan is to have community awareness and involvement.  An informed public will make an evacuation successful.  Once the RMP is submitted to the EPA, the information about the quantities of hazardous chemicals used at this facility and their locations will be made available to the public by the City of Athens Fire Department.  In addition, it is recommended that public service notices be placed in the local paper, as well as also announced over the local radio broadcasts.  These notices should include information concerning how the public will be notified, the eva
cuation route they should take, and where further information will be disseminated.  Property Owner's Associations (POAs) shall also be aware of the emergency response plan
